author: By Charlie Savage
title: As a Public Defender, Supreme Court Nominee Helped Clients Others Avoided
description: Ambitious lawyers usually become prosecutors. Ketanji Brown Jackson worked on behalf of criminal defendants and Guantánamo detainees.
content: WASHINGTON — After the Supreme Court’s landmark 2004 ruling that Guantánamo Bay prisoners could file lawsuits challenging their indefinite detention, the federal public defender in the District of Columbia took on several such cases and assigned a young lawyer in his office to handle them: Ketanji Brown Jackson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Astead W. Herndon
title: At CPAC, Ukraine and Policy Take a Back Seat to Cultural Grievances
description: The annual gathering of American conservatives reflected the G.O.P’s shift away from policy issues that had traditionally animated the party.
content: ORLANDO, Fla. — Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has much of the world transfixed and on edge. President Biden announced a new Supreme Court appointment who is unlikely to get any significant Republican support.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Huge Verdict Buoys Workers Poisoned by Dust
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, February 26, 2020.
content: “That’s one way I don’t want to go. Let someone shoot me. I don’t want to be dunked underwater or strangled. That’s what it feels like.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: For Ukraine’s Refugees, Europe Opens Doors That Were Shut to Others
description: Thousands of Ukrainians will end up in countries led by nationalist governments that have been reluctant to welcome refugees in the past.
content: WASHINGTON — Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has pushed tens of thousands of people out of their homes and fleeing across borders to escape violence. But unlike the refugees who have flooded Europe in crises over the past decade, they are being welcomed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Tyler Perry’s A Madea Homecoming’ Review: Tyler’s Hard Lemonade
description: Tyler Perry revives his signature character — this time for Netflix — in a fast, nonsensical new Madea movie.
content: Midway through “Tyler Perry’s A Madea Homecoming,” there’s a gag that captures the humor of Perry’s multimedia Madea franchise. Perry halts the plot for a black-and-white flashback where his short-tempered, unfiltered titular matriarch tells the story of how she kick-started the Civil Rights movement by threatening her man’s mistress, Rosa Parks, who then took sanctuary on a Montgomery bus. As proof, Madea brandishes a photo she took in the moment on her smartphone. “My aPhone,” she says, “because they didn’t have iPhone back then — it was A before I.” It’s unapologetic, irreverent nonsense — but it should get a laugh, so why not? Perry, who claimed that he would retire his signature character after 2019’s “A Madea Family Funeral,” has resurrected Madea, it seems, in that same spirit: simply because he can.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: Russia Intensifies Censorship Campaign, Pressuring Tech Giants
description: Google, Apple and others were warned that they must comply with a new law, which would make them more vulnerable to the Kremlin’s censorship demands.
content: As Russia attacks Ukraine, the authorities in Moscow are intensifying a censorship campaign at home by squeezing some of the world’s biggest tech companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike McIntire and Michael Forsythe
title: Putin Faces Sanctions, but His Assets Remain an Enigma
description: On paper, the Russian president appears to own very little. Yet estimates put his hidden wealth well over $100 billion.
content: When Western governments announced on Friday their intention to freeze assets belonging to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia as punishment for invading Ukraine, there was no indication they knew of significant holdings that could be tied to him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chisom Peter Job
title: ‘Euphoria’ Star Angus Cloud Offers Hints About Season Finale
description: The actor plays Fezco, the kindhearted drug dealer who watches over Rue.
content: Name: Angus Cloud
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: U.S. Eases Sanctions to Allow Routine Transactions With Afghan Government
description: The move allows financial dealings with civil servants at government institutions, even if those ministries are now overseen by Taliban members.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration moved on Friday to relax sanctions that have contributed to the collapse of Afghanistan’s economy since the Taliban takeover in August, issuing a measure that makes clear that people can lawfully engage in transactions with the Afghan government in most circumstances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bridgette Bartlett Royall
title: The Enduring Significance of Jumping the Broom
description: Once a symbolic way for enslaved people in the American South to recognize their marriages, modern couples say that this tradition is a way to honor those who did it before them.
content: The tradition of jumping the broom at weddings has a long history that encompasses different cultures and continents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins, Eric Schmitt, Michael Levenson and The New York Times
title: Russia Advances on 3 Ukrainian Cities, but Meets Fierce Resistance
description: Ukraine’s leader said his forces had “repelled” the Russian army’s assault. Moscow claimed it had merely “paused” for the possibility of peace negotiations.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — The Ukrainian military, outmanned and outgunned, waged ferocious, close-range battles on Saturday to maintain control of the capital, Kyiv, and other cities around the country as intense street fighting broke out on the third day of the Russian invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Lynsey Addario
title: ‘Everybody in Our Country Needs to Defend’
description: Civilian volunteers and paramilitary groups are taking the fight to the Russian army in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Glass shards, bits of metal and shell casings, the detritus from a fierce and lethal street fight in Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv, lay scattered over hundreds of yards of pavement. Leading away from the site were bloody footprints.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Ukrainian forces slow Russian advance as the U.S. and its allies take action on Russian banks.
description: Through intense fighting in the streets of Kyiv and other cities on Sunday, Ukraine’s defense forces and civilian volunteers resisted Russia’s invasion for a fourth day, battling for control of the capital as international pressure mounted on Moscow and support for Kyiv’s besieged government grew.
content: Through intense fighting in the streets of Kyiv and other cities on Sunday, Ukraine’s defense forces and civilian volunteers resisted Russia’s invasion for a fourth day, battling for control of the capital as international pressure mounted on Moscow and support for Kyiv’s besieged government grew.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: A Kennedy’s Crusade Against Covid Vaccines Anguishes Family and Friends
description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has risen to become a major figure in the vaccine resistance movement. Those close to him say it’s “heartbreaking.”
content: Kerry Kennedy remembers how much she admired her older brother Robert as they grew up in Hickory Hill, the family estate in McLean, Va. She still talks about how he took her along to ford streams, crawl through drainpipes and catch frogs and snakes, ignoring his friends who did not want a 6-year-old girl tagging behind on their outdoor adventures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: New Amazon Headquarters Sparks Feud Among Indigenous South Africans
description: The development, still under construction, sits on sacred land in Cape Town. But some Indigenous leaders have allied with the developers, prompting a debate over who speaks for First Nations people.
content: CAPE TOWN — On a swath of grassy land with an open view of Cape Town’s picturesque Table Mountain, a squad of yellow tractors cleared the lot for a new $300 million commercial and residential development that has stirred up debate in South Africa not just for its location, but also for its anchor tenant: the tech giant Amazon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Retired SWAT Commander Acquitted in Fatal Shooting of Moviegoer
description: Curtis J. Reeves Jr. said he acted in self-defense after a dispute that led a man to toss a bag of popcorn at him in a Florida movie theater in 2014.
content: A jury in Florida on Friday acquitted a retired SWAT commander who shot and killed a man more than eight years ago inside a movie theater after a dispute over cellphone use.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Berkshire Hathaway Rebounds From the Pandemic
description: In announcing the company’s $90 billion profit in 2021, Warren Buffett noted the role that Berkshire plays in the American economy.
content: Warren E. Buffett is eager to make one point clear about Berkshire Hathaway, the conglomerate he controls: It is a good corporate American citizen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: The C.D.C. releases new masking guidance and Queen Elizabeth tests positive: The week in Covid news.
description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention released new guidance this week under which more than two-thirds of the country will no longer be advised to wear masks.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention released new guidance this week under which more than two-thirds of the country will no longer be advised to wear masks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Putin’s War Ushers In Crisis for Russia
description: Despite the Kremlin’s efforts to obscure the offensive in Ukraine, the costs of the war were already evident in both economic and social turmoil.
content: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin has ushered in a crisis for his country — in its economy and identity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman and Melissa Eddy
title: They Do Business in Russia, and Now They May Pay a Price
description: European companies that have operations in Russia are preparing for collateral damage as Western sanctions aim to penalize Russia’s economy.
content: PARIS — French energy companies operating in Russia’s Arctic Sea. Italian luxury boutiques near Red Square. German auto factories around the Russian south.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: Russia vetoes a U.N. Security Council resolution calling on it to withdraw from Ukraine.
description: Eleven countries voted in favor of the U.S.-backed measure, and three abstained.
content: Russia on Friday vetoed a United Nations Security Council resolution of which it was the target, effectively blocking action by the panel, which is responsible for protecting and maintaining international peace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: U.S. Oil Industry Uses Ukraine Invasion to Push for More Drilling at Home
description: The goal is “energy security,” lobbyists said, although clean-energy advocates counter that wind and solar provide more protection from boom-and-bust oil markets.
content: Russian troops hadn’t yet begun their full-on assault on Ukraine late Wednesday when the rallying cry came from the American oil and gas industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden and Putin, Children of the Cold War, Face Off in New Conflict
description: Not since John F. Kennedy and Nikita S. Khrushchev confronted each other over Berlin and Cuba have an American president and Russian leader gone eyeball to eyeball in quite such a dramatic fashion.
content: WASHINGTON — As President Biden tells the story, he was blunt with Vladimir V. Putin during a meeting in Moscow more than a decade ago. “I’m looking into your eyes, and I don’t think you have a soul,” Mr. Biden recalled telling the K.G.B. veteran. Mr. Putin smiled. “We understand one another,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nadav Gavrielov
title: Landmarks in New York and elsewhere use lights to show support for Ukraine.
description: The landmarks include the World Trade Center, the Eiffel Tower and more.
content: Several New York landmarks are being illuminated in blue and yellow, the colors of the Ukrainian flag, through the weekend as a show of solidarity for the people of Ukraine, Gov. Kathy Hochul said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum and John Koblin
title: Chris Licht, a Creator of ‘Morning Joe’ and ‘Colbert’ Producer, Is Set to Run CNN
description: He will take over CNN as the network gets a new corporate owner. He replaces Jeff Zucker, the network president who abruptly resigned this month.
content: Chris Licht, a veteran television producer who helped create “Morning Joe” at MSNBC and later successfully retooled morning and late-night programming at CBS, is set to be the next leader of CNN, according to three people with direct knowledge of the decision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: What You Need to Know About Facial Recognition at Airports
description: Customs officials aim to save time and increase security by ramping up the use of facial recognition. But what about privacy? A biometrics specialist weighs in.
content: As Americans get more comfortable traveling during the pandemic, international travelers may find a new identification system used by the U. S. Customs and Border Protection agency (C.B.P.) on their return home in the form of biometric facial recognition. Following a directive by Congress’s 9/11 Commission to increase border security by using biometrics, C.B.P. began ramping up the technology in 2018 in a program called Simplified Arrival. Among other biometric measurements available, including iris scans and fingerprints, the agency selected facial recognition, which uses a computer algorithm to compare a picture taken in person at airport immigration or another border checkpoint to the traveler’s passport picture or visa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jody Freeman
title: Will the Supreme Court Frustrate Efforts to Slow Climate Change?
description: Coal companies and Republican-led states are trying to limit the E.P.A.’s authority to limit greenhouse gas emissions in the electric power industry.
content: With Congress doing little on climate change, President Biden must use his executive authority to regulate greenhouse gas emissions across the U.S. economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Manguso
title: An Essayist Navigates the Labyrinth of American Health Care. Barely.
description: In the collection “Cost of Living,” Emily Maloney investigates the costs — emotional, physical and financial — of being sick.
content: COST OF LIVING
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: What Americans Really Think About ‘Critical Race Theory’
description: A new CBS poll is revealing.
content: With the Republican crusade against critical race theory still on full blast in states and localities across the country, I thought it was worth sharing the results of a new CBS poll on race and education that sheds a good deal of light on where the public actually stands on these issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson and Stephanie Saul
title: Judge Strikes Down Elite Virginia High School’s Admissions Rules
description: Thomas Jefferson High School eliminated standardized tests and made other changes to attract more Black and Hispanic students. A judge declared the policy unfair to Asian Americans.
content: A federal judge on Friday struck down changes that had been made to the admissions process at a magnet school in Virginia that is one of the most prestigious high schools in the country, saying that the new rules left Asian American students “disproportionately deprived of a level playing field.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher and Ana Swanson
title: Before Ukraine Invasion, Russia and China Cemented Economic Ties
description: Facing a wary United States and worried about depending on imports by sea, China is buying more energy and food from its northern neighbor.
content: BEIJING — As Russia wreaks havoc in Ukraine, Moscow has a powerful economic ally to help it resist Western sanctions: China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin
title: Russia’s Ukraine Invasion Raises Questions About Energy Policy
description: Daniel Yergin, the author of several books about geopolitics and oil, talked with DealBook about the complicated relationship between renewable energy and energy security.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Canada approves a second vaccine made without mRNA technology.
description: The clearance given to a plant-based offering developed by Medicago of Quebec City only covers people ages 18 to 64.
content: Canada’s drug regulator has approved a plant-based coronavirus vaccine that may be a palatable alternative for people who have worried, despite evidence to the contrary, about the safety of the mRNA technology behind vaccines like those made by Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: Foxes, Lawyers and Londoners
description: Our critic recommends old and new books.
content: Hello, readers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Dogs Will Be Dogs. But How Much Barking Is Too Much for Neighbors?
description: City dwellers are expected to tolerate some amount of noise. When it comes to disruptive pets, you need to prove it’s a problem.
content: Q: I live in a rent-stabilized apartment in Brooklyn. My neighbor across the hall has two large dogs that bark incessantly, which triggers my migraines. When I brought my health concerns to my neighbor’s attention, he was hostile and filed a report to the building accusing me of harassment. Management has been reluctant to take a stance. And I don’t have solidarity with my other neighbors, who seem to ignore the chaos. Is there anything that can be done to curb the noise?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Downes
title: Here’s how to find the C.D.C.’s new pandemic guidelines for your area.
description: The guidance is not binding, so local requirements may still apply. The federal mask requirement on mass transit and air travel is set to expire on March 18.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has created a straightforward online tool that can help people see whether their area is at high, medium or low community risk for the coronavirus, the deciding factor in the new guidelines the agency released on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane O'Neill
title: Sheltering in Kyiv While Showing in New York
description: A showroom in NoHo highlights six designers with roots and family in the country.
content: In a showroom in the NoHo section of Manhattan, a laptop sat on a table, tucked behind a rack of knitwear by the Ukrainian label 91 Lab. The computer streamed CNN silently. Ominous footage from the streets of Kyiv, the capital of Ukraine, caught the eye of Alina Bairamova, the fashion industry coordinator for Ukrainian Fashion, a showcase for Ukrainian designers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: State Dept. Says Moscow’s Ukraine Diplomacy Was a ‘Pretense’
description: Officials in the Biden administration met repeatedly with Russian emissaries as the threat of an invasion of Ukraine grew more apparent.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration said on Friday that Russia was never serious about finding a diplomatic solution to the crisis over Ukraine, and that weeks of back-and-forth between Washington and Moscow amounted to a sham as the Kremlin prepared for war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: A Rare Face-to-Face Meeting as M.L.B.’s Deadline Nears
description: Commissioner Rob Manfred had not met Tony Clark, the head of the players’ union, since before the lockout began. Progress was made but time is running out.
content: JUPITER, Fla. — And on the 85th day of baseball’s lockout, they met.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Big tech is betting that offices are still the future.
description: Big tech companies like Meta and Google were among the first to announce during the pandemic that they would allow some employees to work from home permanently, but they have also been spending billions of dollars expanding their office spaces.
content: Big tech companies like Meta and Google were among the first to announce during the pandemic that they would allow some employees to work from home permanently, but they have also been spending billions of dollars expanding their office spaces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashish Jha
title: We’ve Entered a New Phase of the Pandemic. It’s Time for New Metrics.
description: Why the new C.D.C. recommendations make sense.
content: New guidelines from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for community masking are a welcome change. They are reasonable, well-timed and consistent with the science that needs to be guiding the United States’ pandemic response. They also mark a turning point for how people, institutions and governments should respond to the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: The Comforts of Nostalgia
description: Popular culture is taking us back to the past.
content: When the present moment is stressful or uncomfortable, when the future seems especially fuzzy or uncertain, nostalgia offers a balm. It’s why many of us turned to “Friends” reunions, “Sopranos” re-binges and childhood video games  earlier in the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Putin’s critics call for boycotts of Russian vodka.
description: The governors of New Hampshire and Ohio announced measures aimed halting the sales of Russian-made and Russian-branded spirits.
content: Vodka, a drink that was popularized in the West by James Bond and that has long been one of Russia’s most visible exports, is now the target of international anger over the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: Supporters Seek Clemency for Native American Activist Convicted in Killings
description: Leonard Peltier, sentenced to two life terms 45 years ago in the shooting of two F.B.I. agents, is now 77 and in poor health.
content: WASHINGTON — Since 1977, Leonard Peltier, a Native American activist, has been serving two life sentences in federal prison for his role in the killings of two F.B.I. agents during a shootout in 1975 on the Pine Ridge reservation in South Dakota — a punishment that his supporters have long held was the product of an unfair prosecution and a flawed trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham, Elizabeth Dias, Miriam Jordan and Karen Zraick
title: For Some Americans, Ukraine’s Fight Feels Close to Home
description: The Russian invasion deeply affects Ukrainians in the United States, but it also resonates with a 100-year-old Holocaust survivor in Texas and a Taiwanese American family in Georgia.
content: They refreshed their newsfeeds and prayed. They tried to sleep, and didn’t. Some feared for loved ones they worried over by name. Others felt the conflict in Ukraine filtered through their own experiences, shifting their plans and their sense of stability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: How a High School Debate Team Shaped Ketanji Brown Jackson
description: The Supreme Court nominee honed her oratory on Miami Palmetto’s powerhouse debate team. She was not the only alum who went on to an impressive career.
content: PINECREST, Fla. — Let Miami Palmetto Senior High School brag for a moment: It has a swoon-worthy alumni roster. The Amazon founder Jeff Bezos, class of ’82. Dr. Vivek H. Murthy, the United States surgeon general, class of ’94. And Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson, the first Black woman nominated to the Supreme Court, class of ’88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Alan Feuer
title: Jan. 6 Panel Threatens to Force Guilfoyle to Testify After She Ends Interview
description: Kimberly Guilfoyle, the fiancée of former President Donald J. Trump’s eldest son, cut short an interview when she learned that House members on the panel were participating.
content: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol said on Friday that it would compel Kimberly Guilfoyle, the fiancée of former President Donald J. Trump’s eldest son, to testify after she abruptly ended a voluntary interview with the panel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: Putin Seems to Sideline Advisers on Ukraine, Taking a Political Risk
description: Authoritarian leaders rely on elite support to govern. Jeopardizing those relationships in wartime could be risky, experts say.
content: Does President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia have the support he needs at home to wage a costly war in Ukraine?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: As battle for Kyiv rages, Ukraine’s president tries to rally his people.
description: “We have withstood and successfully repelled enemy attacks,” President Volodymyr Zelensky said in the video. “The fighting continues in many cities and districts of our state, but we know that we protect the country, the land, the future of children.”
content: KYIV, Ukraine — As Russian troops lay siege to Kyiv, the president of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky, again appeared on camera on Saturday to furnish proof of his continued presence in his country’s capital, praise his outgunned and outmanned military and beseech Western countries for more support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David A. Kaplan
title: A Medical Mystery Posed by Blurred Lanes
description: As I was driving during a cross-country road trip, my vision became wobbly. An extensive search for a specialist followed.
content: Our cross-country drive last winter from New York to Lake Tahoe was going to be eventful enough, with a pandemic, blizzards and the cancellation of salads at McDonald’s. But by Omaha, when the lanes on Interstate 80 seemed to be bouncing around before my very eyes, we entered unexpected territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Cinemagrams
description: Sheldon Polonsky sets a spectacular scene in his Sunday puzzle debut.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — I wish I could roll out a red carpet for this one! We need some paparazzi, too, and a golden statuette, although it might look more like the Rodin sculpture “The Thinker,” a figure in deep thought over how to unscramble 21 letters. (I hope that’s not a spoiler.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trayvon Martin Is Still Making America Confront Its Original Sin
description: Not every killing connects with the culture and activates a mass movement. This one did.
content: “One of the most important things that came out of this tragedy was the activation of an entire new generation of civil rights leaders.” That was part of what President Barack Obama told The Times when we asked him what the killing of Trayvon Martin, 10 years ago Saturday, meant for the United States, the movement for civil rights and for him personally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: Biden Made a Historic Supreme Court Pick. What Now?
description: Nominating the first Black woman is both bold and politically savvy, Democrats told us. Republicans are divided over how much of a fight to put up.
content: When word first leaked Friday that President Biden had chosen Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson as the first Black woman to serve on the Supreme Court, Democrats and civil rights activists were ecstatic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: It Makes Waves
description: Ori Brian’s Saturday puzzle is enough to curl your hair.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is a pretty tough Saturday debut by Ori Brian, who has previously constructed grids for The Times for every work day — unless you work on Saturdays as I do (or consider solving the puzzle to be work, which I do not). I got the bird references all wrong and failed at several names in the trivia clues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins, Andrew E. Kramer and Michael Levenson
title: Ukraine Girds for Kyiv Attack Amid Signs of Slowing Russian Advance
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky warned in a video address that Russian “sabotage groups” had entered Kyiv with the aim of decapitating his government by “destroying the head of state.”
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Ukraine braced for an all-out assault on its capital early Saturday, after a day in which the military blew up a bridge to slow the advance of Russian soldiers, street fights erupted in a northern district of the city, and the nation’s leaders warned residents that Russia wanted to “bring the capital to its knees.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Muyi Xiao, Brenna Smith, Malachy Browne and Sarah Kerr
title: Video shows a missile hitting a residential building in Kyiv.
description: The missile hit a building about 1.5 miles from Sikorsky Memorial Airport.
content: Videos and photos verified by The New York Times showed a residential building struck by a missile in southwestern Kyiv, about 1.5 miles from Sikorsky Memorial Airport, on Saturday morning. Videos showed rescue and evacuation efforts underway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sasha Vasilyuk
title: My Family Never Asked to Be ‘Liberated’
description: But war came to them.
content: My 70-year-old aunt had planned a quiet week. A bit of ironing, planting petunias in the garden and maybe finally tackling an unwieldy tangle of electrical chargers. Instead, she sits with my uncle, watching the Russian invasion on their laptops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Haramis
title: Finding Love, One Nugget at a Time
description: Amelia Dimoldenberg, a comedian and YouTube host, has amassed a Gen Z following, mixing poultry and romance on her show “Chicken Shop Date.”
content: The deep fryer had only begun to sizzle when Amelia Dimoldenberg was informed that her date for the afternoon, a drill rapper named Bandokay, was scheduled to arrive any minute with his girlfriend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Stranded Soccer Stars, Frantic Phone Calls and a Race to Flee Kyiv
description: “We are here asking for your help,” one Brazilian player pleaded. “There’s no way we can get out.”
content: Inside the windowless conference room of the Kyiv hotel where the soccer stars had gathered, the anxiety was growing by the minute. An aborted attempt to flee had been a disaster. And the sounds of war — mortar fire, rocket blasts, screeching warplanes — provided a near constant reminder of their precarious circumstances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval and Michael A. McCoy
title: A Deadly Riot, and Then 3 Trials, 110 Convictions and 19 Executions
description: In what officials now call one the most unjust military trials in the nation’s history, 19 Black soldiers were sentenced to death in 1917 after a clash with the police.
content: [Race/Related is available as a newsletter. Sign up here to get it delivered to your inbox.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: Worried About Stocks? Think of Ukrainians Under Siege First.
description: If you have an investment portfolio or own a home, you’ve probably experienced big gains. Here’s how to use those winnings to help.
content: In the days since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, plenty of people have tried to predict what it will mean for gas prices or interest rates or your investments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: 8 Found Dead After Ferry Fire Off Greece as Grim Search Continues
description: The blaze aboard the Euroferry Olympia burned for most of a week. Hundreds of passengers were rescued, but at least three more are believed missing.
content: ATHENS — Rescuers exploring the charred hull of a passenger ferry that caught fire off the Greek island of Corfu this month have recovered eight bodies and were searching on Saturday for another three, Greek authorities have said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: The Trucks Are Gone From Ottawa, but Their Aftermath Lingers
description: Streets remained blocked in Ottawa, and many issues, including compensation for those who lost income during the protests, are unresolved.
content: With the protesters who blocked its streets and disrupted life in Ottawa for three weeks routed and the Russian invasion of Ukraine underway, attention to the blockade of the Canadian capital by truckers and other protesters who rejected pandemic measures is fast fading. But while the protest may be over, its effects continue to linger in the city’s downtown and much remains to sort out in its aftermath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mona El-Naggar
title: In Mideast, After Decades of War, the Mass Flight From Ukraine Resonates
description: Many in the region took to social media to express sympathy for Ukrainians forced to flee, though their warm welcome in Europe evoked a tinge of bitterness over the treatment of Arab and Muslim migrants.
content: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — The spectacle of a mass flight out of Ukraine was resonating deeply in the Middle East on Saturday, with many taking to social media to express their sympathy and to commiserate with the plight of those now forced to flee their homes amid a Russian military invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Putin’s Aggression Leaves His Right-Wing Fan Club Squirming
description: The Russian strongman has for years been idolized by a Who’s Who of populist, nationalist leaders. They are now stumbling over what to say.
content: ROME — For years, a global choir of right-wing politicians have sung the praises of Vladimir V. Putin. They looked up to the Russian strongman as a defender of closed borders, Christian conservatism and bare-chested machismo in an era of liberal identity politics and Western globalization. Fawning over him was a core part of the populist playbook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kravitz Hoeffner
title: Where Are All the Lesbian Bars? Coming to a Place Near You.
description: Around the country, new pop-ups have sought to fill a void left by L.G.B.T.Q.-focused spaces that have closed.
content: For years, people have mourned the slow death of the lesbian bar. Only three are left in New York City, according to the Lesbian Bar Project, and fewer than two dozen total in the United States. The pandemic’s toll on the service industry has not helped. Many L.G.B.T.Q. institutions closed to patrons in the spring of 2020; some never reopened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: As Democrats Cheer Jackson Pick, Republicans Pledge Respectful Review
description: The showdown over Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson’s nomination could be less toxic than other recent Supreme Court confirmations.
content: WASHINGTON — Democrats on Friday promised a swift confirmation process for Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson, celebrating President Biden’s pick for the Supreme Court as Republicans signaled that they had little appetite for a toxic battle over the first Black woman to be nominated for the post.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: How This ‘Progressive Prosecutor’ Balances Politics and Public Safety
description: As his peers around the country face fierce criticism, Eric Gonzalez, the Brooklyn district attorney, is navigating a narrow path so far.
content: On the first Sunday in February, Eric Gonzalez, Brooklyn’s district attorney, sat in the front row at Antioch Baptist Church in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood. The visit was emblematic of Mr. Gonzalez’s approach to criminal justice: Alongside dozens of parishioners, he and several local officials and police leaders listened to music, prayer and a biblical account of healing by faith and touch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: The Drift Wants You to ‘Examine Your Ideas’
description: The lit mag of the moment, founded by two women in their 20s, isn’t afraid to say what’s on its mind.
content: On a mild October morning during last year’s Brooklyn Book Festival, Rebecca Panovka and Kiara Barrow set up their display tent outside Borough Hall. They were there to promote The Drift, the journal of politics, culture and literature that they had started online in the early days of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: On both sides of the Korean Peninsula, eyes are on Washington’s response to Russia.
description: North Korea might decide it’s time to resume weapons tests, to gain more diplomatic leverage with Washington.
content: SEOUL — Both North and South Korea are likely to be closely watching the American response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, though for different reasons, analysts say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, Alan Rappeport and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: The U.S. and Europe will bar some Russian banks from SWIFT.
description: The move, along with new restrictions on Russia’s central bank, represented a significant escalation in the effort to impose severe economic costs on Russia for its invasion of Ukraine.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration and key allies announced on Saturday that they would remove some Russian banks from the SWIFT financial messaging system, essentially barring them from international transactions. They also said they would impose new restrictions on Russia’s central bank to prevent it from using its large international reserves to undermine sanctions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Does Anyone Know What Paper Towels Should Cost?
description: Online shopping was supposed to give consumers more power and freedom. Instead, costs are so fluid that household goods fluctuate almost like Bitcoin.
content: When a holiday toy catalog from Amazon arrived in the mail in late October, Krista Hoffmann noticed something amiss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Demetrios Papademetriou, Top Immigration Scholar, Dies at 75
description: He designed the “Grand Bargain,” an ambitious plan for Mexican immigrants to gain legal status in the U.S., but it collapsed after the terrorist attacks of 9/11.
content: Demetrios Papademetriou, one of the world’s leading immigration scholars and an adviser to numerous governments, international organizations and philanthropies on migration and integration issues, died on Jan. 26 at a hospital in Washington. He was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Rash Putin Razes Ukraine
description: Another insecure male works out his issues in a horrible way.
content: WASHINGTON — What has surprised me most about the history I have lived through is how often we get dragged on demented, destructive rides by leaders who put their personal psychodramas over the public’s well-being.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: A Call to Remember the 200,000 Black Troops Who Helped Save the Union
description: Legislators have introduced a bill to honor their contribution with the Congressional Gold Medal.
content: Their sacrifices were heroic, charging into gunfire on Civil War battlefields. Free Black men from the North took up arms while their family members were still enslaved in the South. They wrote of hope in letters to their wives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Vladimir Putin’s Clash of Civilizations
description: Putin is embracing a more sinister version of the unconstrained vision that once led George W. Bush astray.
content: When the United States, in its hour of hubris, went to war to remake the Middle East in 2003, Vladimir Putin was a critic of American ambition, a defender of international institutions and multilateralism and national sovereignty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer and Benjamin Mueller
title: New Research Points to Wuhan Market as Pandemic Origin
description: Two new studies say the virus was present in animals at the Huanan seafood market in 2019.
content: Two new studies say the virus was present in animals at the Huanan seafood market in 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ang Li and Lucas Lilieholm
title: Ukrainians Flee as Russian Invasion Intensifies
description: Thousands of Ukrainians were forced to leave their homes and make their way to neighboring countries in search of safety as a full-scale Russian assault continued.
content: Thousands of Ukrainians were forced to leave their homes and make their way to neighboring countries in search of safety as a full-scale Russian assault continued.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yousur Al-Hlou, Michael Downey and Masha Froliak
title: ‘No City in Ukraine Is Safe’: Family Escapes Missile Strike in Kyiv
description: After days in a bomb shelter, a family returned to their home in Kyiv for breakfast, and witnessed a missile strike on a neighboring apartment building.
content: After days in a bomb shelter, a family returned to their home in Kyiv for breakfast, and witnessed a missile strike on a neighboring apartment building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah M. Kessel, Quincy G. Ledbetter, Charles M. Blow and Adam B. Ellick
title: Trayvon Martin Is Still Making America Confront Its Original Sin
description: Ten years ago, Trayvon Martin’s killing made America look inward — and reawakened a civil rights movement.
content: Ten years ago, Trayvon Martin’s killing made America look inward — and reawakened a civil rights movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: Thousands Flee Ukraine Into Romania
description: Ukrainians escaping Russia’s invasion crossed into neighboring nations like Romania, creating a backlog at one key border crossing, as at least 19,000 people had reportedly entered the country since the fighting began.
content: Ukrainians escaping Russia’s invasion crossed into neighboring nations like Romania, creating a backlog at one key border crossing, as at least 19,000 people had reportedly entered the country since the fighting began.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A World Moving Toward Autocracy
description: Readers respond to a column by David Brooks about liberalism in crisis in “this dark century.”
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Editors’ Note: Feb. 26, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Feb. 26, 2022.
content: After publication of a book review on Tuesday about Margaret Atwood’s “Burning Questions,” the publisher alerted The Times that the text it had provided to the paper for reviewing and again later for fact-checking went through substantial revisions before the final version of the book was published. An updated review can be read online.
source.name: The New York Times
